WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is seven and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also seven. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic:
You know this kanji means Seven, so let's use that to remember the reading too. Seven is a lucky number, usually, but this time it wasn't so good.
Seven percent is all she got on her test after she cheated (ã—ã¡) on it.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: How unbelievable is it that someone got seven percent on a test, especially if you try to cheat? Imagine the girl you loathe the most from school, and imagine her cheating on the test (it's important it's a girl, because of the "she" part in she cheated (ã—ã¡). Then, imagine your happiness when she's super upset about getting seven percent on it. Serves her right, obviously.

humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: There are many interpretations of " seven ", but there is no conclusion. Among them, " seven " is the first article of " cut ", which is more reasonable. The character " seven " means "ä¸¨" to separate the middle of " one ". Later, " seven " was borrowed as a numeral, so we had to add " knife " to " seven " to make another character " cut " (see Lin Yiguang, Ding mountain). In addition, Zhang Bingquan believes that the origin of the word " seven " comes from gestures, like the shape of two hands intersecting vertically and horizontally. "Said Wen": "Seven, the positive of yang. From the one, the micro-yin comes out of the middle. All the belongings of the seven are from the seven."

In ancient Chinese characters, the shape of " 7 " and "å" are similar but different. The " seven " inscriptions are mostly horizontal and vertical, and the horizontal and vertical strokes are sometimes similar in length, while the " ten " inscriptions are often made in a vertical shape with a small dot in the middle of the vertical stroke. The Chinese character "å" stretches out into a horizontal stroke after the dots, but the character "å" is mostly short and long, sometimes only a vertical shape. In "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips" and "Mawangdui Silk Book", the " seven " characters are almost all written horizontally and vertically. The popular way of writing today is that the Warring States characters are written in the lower part of the vertical to distinguish them from the " ten ". Become. See " ten ". In addition, the " seven " inscriptions on the inscriptions of the word " A " and " A " have the same form, and the two characters can only be distinguished by rhetoric, see " A ".

Oracle bone inscriptions are used as numerals and can be used as ordinal numbers, "He Ji" 6: "July." Or as a base, "He Ji" 20736: "Allow only (get) seven hogs."

Bronze inscriptions are also used as numerals. They can be used as ordinal numbers. Yayu Ding: "The day after the King's Seven Sacrifices" refers to the second day of the King's seventh sacrifice. Also used as the base number, Qin Gong ğ£ª•: "One bucket and seven liters."

The characters of the Warring States Period are used as numerals, "Shangbo Bamboo Book Seven. "Wu Wang Jianhuan" Jane 12-13: "Wu Wangzhai for seven days, Da (Tai) [Gong] Wang Feng Dan Shu ã ¯ (Yi) Dynasty." The word is also known as " cricket ", "Shangbo Bamboo Book I. "Confucius Poetry Theory" Jane 27: ""Seven (cricket)" ğ£‰» (knowledge) difficult." The full sentence refers to "Poetry. Tang Feng. "Cricket" knows the difficulties of the world.

In order to make the fonts not easy to mix, the numbers are often used to replace the original characters with more strokes. The uppercase of " seven " was used in the Han Dynasty with the character "æ¡¼", and later the character " lacquer " was used. " Qi " was originally a variant of " lacquer ". Later, the two characters gradually differentiated. " Qi " was also used exclusively as the capital of " seven " (Qiu Xigui).
humanum_short_description_en: The word " seven " starts from "ä¸€" from "ä¸¨", which means to use "ä¸¨" to cut the " one " from it. "ä¸ƒ" is the initial text of " cut ", which is later borrowed as a number.

Elaboration: There are many interpretations of " seven", but there is no conclusion. Among them, " seven" is the first article of " cut", which is more reasonable. The character " seven" means " ä¸¨" to separate the middle of " one". Later, " seven" was borrowed as a numeral, so we had to add " knife" to " seven" to make another character " cut" (see Lin Yiguang, Ding mountain). In addition, Zhang Bingquan believes that the origin of the word " seven" comes from gestures, like the shape of two hands intersecting vertically and horizontally. "Said Wen": "Seven, the positive of yang. From the one, the micro-yin comes out of the middle. All the belongings of the seven are from the seven." In ancient Chinese characters, the shape of " 7" and " å" are similar but different. The " seven" inscriptions are mostly horizontal and vertical, and the horizontal and vertical strokes are sometimes similar in length, while the " ten" inscriptions are often made in a vertical shape with a small dot in the middle of the vertical stroke. The Chinese character " å" stretches out into a horizontal stroke after the dots, but the character " å" is mostly short and long, sometimes only a vertical shape. In "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips" and "Mawangdui Silk Book", the " seven" characters are almost all written horizontally and vertically. The popular way of writing today is that the Warring States characters are written in the lower part of the vertical to distinguish them from the " ten". Become. See " ten". In addition, the " seven" inscriptions on the inscriptions of the word " A" and " A" have the same form, and the two characters can only be distinguished by rhetoric, see " A". Oracle bone inscriptions are used as numerals and can be used as ordinal numbers, "He Ji" 6: "July." Or as a base, "He Ji" 20736: "Allow only (get) seven hogs." Bronze inscriptions are also used as numerals. They can be used as ordinal numbers. Yayu Ding: "The day after the King's Seven Sacrifices" refers to the second day of the King's seventh sacrifice. Also used as the base number, Qin Gong ğ£ª•: "One bucket and seven liters." The characters of the Warring States Period are used as numerals, "Shangbo Bamboo Book Seven. "Wu Wang Jianhuan" Jane 12-13: "Wu Wangzhai for seven days, Da (Tai) [Gong] Wang Feng Dan Shu ã ¯ (Yi) Dynasty." The word is also known as " cricket", "Shangbo Bamboo Book I. "Confucius Poetry Theory" Jane 27: ""Seven (cricket)" ğ£‰» (knowledge) difficult." The full sentence refers to "Poetry. Tang Feng. "Cricket" knows the difficulties of the world. In order to make the fonts not easy to mix, the numbers are often used to replace the original characters with more strokes. The uppercase of " seven" was used in the Han Dynasty with the character " æ¡¼", and later the character " lacquer" was used. " Qi" was originally a variant of " lacquer". Later, the two characters gradually differentiated. " Qi" was also used exclusively as the capital of " seven" (Qiu Xigui).

Radicals: ä¸ƒ  (seven)
Meaning Mnemonic
Lucky for you (as is the case with many of the lower-stroke kanji), this kanji is the same as the radical you've already learned. The radical that makes up this kanji is seven and the kanji (which is exactly the same) is also seven. So, if you know the radical, you know the meaning of the kanji as well.
Make sure you know your radicals well and you'll be A-Okay on this one!
Reading Mnemonic
You know this kanji means Seven, so let's use that to remember the reading too. Seven is a lucky number, usually, but this time it wasn't so good.
Seven percent is all she got on her test after she cheated (ã—ã¡) on it.
How unbelievable is it that someone got seven percent on a test, especially if you try to cheat? Imagine the girl you loathe the most from school, and imagine her cheating on the test (it's important it's a girl, because of the "she" part in she cheated (ã—ã¡). Then, imagine your happiness when she's super upset about getting seven percent on it. Serves her right, obviously.
